section.title: Game setting and goal
section.para: Two teams fight against on a large map. Each team consists of a maximum of 5 players. The first team that destroys enemy base wins. A single player mode is not planned.

section.title: General game cycle
section.para: Both teams start randomly at either top-left or bottom-right corner of map (yes, this is contrary to common multiplayer maps like LOL. That's intended.). Teams spread into the map trying to conquer neutral bases that are spread all over the map. Then they will move forward to enemy base.

section.title: Neutral bases
section.para: Neutral bases can be conquered by a team. Once a base is conquered it should be defended against enemy team. If defence fails, enemy team can conquer the neutral base to optain its benefits.

Neutral bases consist of a tower surrounded by some buildings. The tower provides some basic vision (see advantages) and is the central key of the base. A player can conquer a base by right-clicking its tower and channeling until control switched to his team. An already conquered base must be "neutralized" first. Buildings of a base can protect players because they block vision.

section.title: Advantages
section.para: A neutral base provides several benefits to current controlling team:

listitem.para: Vision: The base provides slight vision around the base.
Regeneration: Team mates will regenerate some portion of their health while staying in base without fighting.
More units: Players can control siege machines and/or footmen that can be produced in that base.
(fma) Some kind of 'money': Controlling a base should generate some kind of resource which can be used to buy units or do some other actions. The more bases you control, the more money you get.

section.title: Disadvantages
section.para: To provide some team balance, holding neutral bases should have some negative aspects:

listitem.para: Backdooring: Each base has at least two or three entrances.
Vulnerability: Bases have no defence towers or something like this. You must defend them with your team.
No defence: Units spawned in that base cannot be moved or kept inside its centrum, so they have to defend with their team itself.

section.title: Shooting
section.para: Players can launch missiles to shoot enemies like in Counter Strike. (fma) The variety of available weapons may look like in Quake, where each weapon feels very distinct to the others and serves another purpose. The weapon balancing is much greater than in 'realistic' shooters like Counter-Strike or Call Of Duty, in which all weapons feel more or less the same. (/fma)

section.title: Controlling units
section.para: Once in a base, a player can choose to stay there for a while and control units instead of running around the map. If he does so, he gains control over most units that spawn in that base. That might behave similar to Warcraft 3. Players can use these units to ambush enemy team or fight forward towards their base. There are also some defensive units that can heal or chop trees down.

Players controlling units are not safe from attacks by enemies. Staying in a neutral base controlled by you can be dangerous due to vulnerability of these bases. A player is not able to move or interact with his game-figure while controlling units. That makes unit-controlling risky. To ensure survival, a team has to stick together and protect an ally that controls units.
